newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani newspapers want Afghan policy review.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani newspapers want Afghan policy review.

text.p: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government was urged by Pakistani newspapers on Friday to review its policy towards Afghanistan as the Taleban Islamic militia took control of the capital Kabul.
"The fast-moving developments in Afghanistan call for urgent consultations and a comprehensive review of the Afghan policy," the English-language daily The Nation said.
It said there should be a serious endavour in Islamabad to quantify the implications of a Taleban takeover in Afghanistan.
No Pakistan government comments on Kabul's fall were immediately available because of the Islamic weekend here.
"The Taleban are an unknown quantity in terms of their political orientation, barring the vague perception that they are a religious-motivated outfit," The Nation said.

The Taleban movement burst on to the Afghan scene in late 1994 after it was formed by Islamic religious students led by Mullah Muhammad Omar, a former guerrilla fighter who was wounded several times in battles with Soviet soldiers in the 1980s.

"Unfortunately the Iranians are averse to Taleban, which makes the scenario even more intricate and calls for an extremely cautious approach to harmonise conflicting interests in the Afghan settlement," The Nation said.
"Preserving Pakistan's friendly ties with Iran is above all an imperative of the region's geo-politics and Islamabad will have to be prepared for the delicate balancing act."
The Peshawar-based Frontier Post said the best solution for Afghanistan would have to be found through talks among all factions.
"A solution on the basis of force cannot be a lasting one. The Taleban, or for that matter, other strong Afghan groups, must realise that they cannot dictate terms for long."

The mass circulation Urdu language daily Nawa-i-Waqt (voice of the time) said the United States and Pakistan had been accused of supporting Taleban and that did not augur well for the national interest of the country.
"President Farooq Leghari should review Pakistan's foreign policy towards Afghanistan," it urged.
President Burhanuddin Rabbani's government, which fled Kabul before the city's fall, has often accused Pakistan of helping the Taleban but Pakistan denies the charge.
"We reject these accusations with the contempt they deserve," a Pakistan Foreign Ministry spokesman said on Thursday.
"We have had and will continue to observe total neutrality while we must maintain a close watch on the events as they develop."
